Shell cap-shaped, medium in size, fairly tall and relatively light. External surface with about 50 fine alternately weaker and stronger ribs that hardly break the smooth, oval outline. Ribs patterned with white scales when in good condition, but frequently shell very eroded, smoothing the ribs and exposing a brown cap. Interior of shell with a dark border and a brown centre, separated by a white band.

The fact that this species occurs higher on the shore than other limpets is also a useful identification feature.
Shell up to about 60 mm in length.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to Eastern Cape.

An extremely common species that is restricted to the intertidal and most abundant high on the shore, extending well up into the barnacle zone. Maintains a home scar, where the profile of the shell exactly matches that of the rock. Undertakes feeding excursions both at high tide and when the weather is cool, rainy or misty, and is very effective at maintaining the rock surfaces free of algae. This can be demonstrated by placing exclusion cages, or painting closed circles or squares of anti-fouling paint onto the rock, which the limpets will not cross. Within a few weeks excluded areas become completely coated with algae!

Much of the habitat originally occupied by this species has become monopolized by the invasive Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis and there was initially concern that the limpets would be severely impacted, but research has demonstrated that they in fact not only survive but attain a higher density and reproductive output in mussel beds than on un-invaded rocks. They do this by living on the shell valves of individual mussels, which cumulatively provide a much larger surface area than the smooth rock. Although growth is much slower on these restricted territories, the limpets still reach sexual maturity and breed there. Thus mussel beds support a larger number of smaller ‘bonsai’ limpets than were present before invasive mussels established and altered the upper shore.

Growth rates are highly variable between sites, generally being faster on the west coast. The size at one year of age varies from about 20-40 mm and longevity has been estimated at about 6-7 years.
Herbivorous, diet depending largely on height on the shore. High-shore individuals feed largely on black lichens and those at lower levels also on a wide range of algal species.

Sexes are separate and the sex ratio has been measured at between 66 and 72 females per 100 males. Gonads reached maximum size in May with spawning taking place in June and July. Fecundity varies widely at between 400 000 and 1.7 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.

The granular external texture and ability to survive higher on the shore than other similar limpets make this species fairly easy to identify. Replaced in KwaZulu-Natal by the very similar S. natalensis, which has black granules on the ribs.
